text: Since \( 3n^2 + 3n + 7 \equiv 1 \pmod{3} \), it must be the case that \( x^3 \equiv 1 \pmod{3} \), implying \( x \equiv 1 \pmod{3} \).

text: The only value of \( x \equiv 5 \pmod{9} \) satisfies \( x^3 \equiv 7 \pmod{9} \).

text: However, this doesn't match with \( x \equiv 1 \pmod{3} \) derived first.

text: Thus, it is impossible for both conditions to hold simultaneously for any integer \( x \).

class-2-reason: The sentence concludes that it is impossible for both conditions to be true, which functions as a verification of incompatibility.
